vocabulary.example: pancake mix [n] - powder (flour) to make pancakes
I swear [exp] - I promise
fractions [n] - a type of math (¼ + ½ = , ⅔ x ⅚ = )
diapers [n] - the shorts that babies (and old people) wear before they can use the toilet
shell [n] - the outside of an egg
calcium [n] - the nutrient in milk (and eggshells) that is good for your bones and teeth
you old fucker [exp] - you old friend
on the road [exp] - on our way to the destination (while we are driving)
concrete [n] - like cement, used in construction
pour (concrete) [v] - one step in making a house foundation using concrete
frame (concrete) [v] - another step in making a house foundation using concrete
work a double [exp] - work a double shift, work overtime
split it [exp] - divide the money between two or more people
the Middle East [n] - western Asia (Iran, Iraq, Turkey, etc...)
It doesn't ring a bell [exp] - It is not familiar. I don't know. I cannot remember
not mutually exclusive [exp] - not always separate or different
drop (someone) off [phv] - take someone to place, usually by car
inside out [adj] - clothing that has the inside part facing outwards
asking after you [exp] - asking about you
biscuits [n] - a type of bread (made with flour)
Atkins [n] - a type of diet in which you don't eat bread (eat mainly protein and fat)
Solid! [exp] - Awesome! Great!
Put that out [phv] - Extinguish that! (Throw away your cigarette)

questions.question: There is some eggshell in Joel's eggs.
There is enough food for Tommy.
Joel thinks that 'love' and 'dependent' are the same.
Joel wants to hire another worker so that they can finish earlier.
Joel is going to have to work late today.
Sarah promises to get a cake for Joel.
Jakarta is in the Middle East.
Joel and Tommy are good at geography.
Joel eats some of the neighbor's biscuits.
Sarah says she will visit the neighbors later.
Joel doesn't want Tommy to smoke in the truck.

grammar.explanation: Choose the word and place in the sentence that most logically connects the ideas in the sentence. Use words like: did, for, how, are, is, until, with, and, but, where, have, she. Some boxes will be empty.

exercises.sentence: I was going to make you birthday pancakes ___ my benefit.
He's dependent on me. It's not the same. I think it ___ the same.
I'm not splitting this job ___ you.
I'll bring back a cake ___ I promise.
We'll drop you off ___ you got seven minutes.
Connie was asking after you, since you haven't been over ___ a while.
We ___ got to run, ___ Sarah will be by later.
___ will tell you all about Atkins.
Put that out ___ Happy Birthday to you.

transcript.full:
Sarah: Where is the pancake mix?

Joel: Oh, was I... Yeah, I was. Sorry.

Sarah: I was going to make you birthday pancakes. I swear.

Joel: You know I don't really like pancakes.

Sarah: I know you don't like them. It was for my benefit. Vitamin C.

Joel: (Did) You get your homework done? Fractions?

Sarah: How old are you again?

Joel: Thirty-six.

Sarah: You are going to have to wear diapers soon.

Joel: Who says I don't already? Shell.

Sarah: Calcium.

Joel: Lovely. Is there enough for Uncle Tommy?

Sarah: There would've been.

Tommy: Ay! You're still alive, you old fucker.

Sarah: Aw, he loves you.

Joel: He's dependent on me. It's not the same.

Sarah: I think it's the same.

Tommy: It's definitely the same. I thought we was having pancakes.

Joel: We'll pick you something up on the road. Are the concrete guys going to be there?

Tommy: Yeah, they said maybe.

Joel: Maybe? We can't frame until we pour. We're not getting paid until we frame.

Tommy: Well, we could bring someone else on, and get the job done faster.

Joel: No, no. I'm not splitting this job. I barely want to split it with you. We could work a double.

Sarah: Literally? Today?

Joel: I know. I'd be done by nine. By nine, right?

Tommy: Yeah.

Joel: I'll bring back a cake. I promise.

Radio: ...continued disturbances in Jakarta, but are advising U.S. citizens...

Joel: Jakarta. Where is that, Middle East?

Tommy: It doesn't ring a bell. It's definitely a country. Or maybe part of Asia?

Sarah: Jakarta isn't a country. Being a part of Asia isn't mutually exclusive with being a country, and in fact, it's the capital of Indonesia.

Tommy: Shit. (There is) Hope for us yet.

Joel: All right. Finish up quick. We'll drop you off.

Sarah: I'm still eating my eggshells.

Joel: You got seven minutes.

Sarah: Your t-shirt is inside out.

Joel: Shit.

Tommy: He's losing it.

Mr. Adler: Hey, neighbor!

Sarah: Oh, hi.

Mr. Adler: Uh, Connie was asking after you, since you haven't been over in a while.

Joel: Make them happy.

Sarah: I could come by after school, but just for, like, a little bit?

Mr. Adler: Oh, she'll take what you got. Y'all can bake, whatever. Speaking of, we got a lot of extra here. Y'all, y'all want some biscuits?

Sarah: Dad, you love biscuits.

Joel: I do. But I'm on Atkins.

Mr. Adler: On what now?

Joel: It's... You know what? We (have) got to run, but Sarah will be by later. She'll stay as long as you want. (She will) Tell you all about Atkins.

Mr. Adler: Great! I'll let Connie know.

Sarah: Solid.

Tommy: I can't tell you how exciting it was listening to that fucking conversation.

Joel: Put that out.

Tommy: Happy Birthday to you.
